title: Scotland to introduce ‘latte levy’ on single-use plastic cups
text:
Coffee drinkers could be charged extra for disposable coffee cups (Picture:vitpluz@gmail.com)

Coffee drinkers could be charged an extra 25p for disposable plastic cups under proposed new legislation in Scotland.

Holyrod are introducing a charge for single-use plastic cups under the Circular Economy Bill, which is expected to come into force next year if passed.

The price of the so called ‘latte tax’ has yet to be set, but environmental advisors have previously said a charge of 20 to 25p could help reduce waste.

200 million single-use coffee cups are discarded every year in Scotland.

Although disposable cups are made of paper, most have a waterproof plastic lining that makes them difficult to recycle unless they are collected separately and taken to specialist recycling facilities.

200 million coffee cups get sent to landfill in Scotland each year (Picture: DPA)

An environmental panel suggested introducing a national, mandatory requirement to sell drinks and disposable cups separately in July.

Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said a ‘fundamental rethink’ was needed for Scotland to meet its climate ambitions of becoming a net-zero nation by 2045.

If the tax is successful in reducing waste, the charge could then be applied to other items proven to cause environmental harm in the future.

The Scottish Government has already outlined plans for a deposit return scheme for plastic drinking containers, cans and glass.

Under the scheme, a 20p deposit will be added to the price of a single-use drinks container bought from a shop, which the consumer will get back when they return it to the retailer.

A similar 15p scheme for England and Wales is being consulted on.

Although coffee cups are made of paper they have a waterproof lining that makes them difficult to recycle (Picture: iStockphoto)

However, plans for a latte levy were ruled out by then Chancellor Philip Hammond last year.

Instead of applying a tax, ministers decided it was better for shops to offer voluntary discounts for customers who bring their own cup.

description: Scotland to introduce tax on single-use plastic cups to reduce waste
